{{Distinguish|fossil fuel divestment}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Sustainable energy}} [[File:US-WA-Olympia-Capitol-StopCoalTrain-2013.01.14-013.JPG|thumb|Protest at the Legislative Building in [[Olympia, Washington]]. Ted Nation an activist for several decades beside protest sign]] [[File:Farmington-Mine-Disaster-smoke.jpg|thumb|upright|The 1968 [[Farmington Mine disaster|Farmington coal mine disaster]] kills 78 in West Virginia, [[United States|US]] ]] [[File:Defense.gov photo essay 100421-G-0000L-003.jpg|thumb|The 2010 [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill]] discharges 4.9 million barrels]] '''Fossil fuel phase out''' refers to the discontinuation of the use of [[fossil fuels]], through the decommissioning of operating [[Fossil-fuel power station|fossil fuel-fired power plants]], the prevention of the construction of new ones, and the use of [[alternative energy]] to replace the role of fossil fuels.
The purpose of fossil fuel phase-out is to reduce the negative [[externalities]] that use of fossil fuels cause. Negative externalities refer to the costs a certain activity has over people who did not choose to incur in them. A direct negative externality from fossil fuels' use is [[air pollution]], and an indirect negative externality are [[mining accidents]], that happen as a consequence of the extraction of fossil fuels. Fossil fuel burning contributes to [[climate change]], as it releases [[greenhouse gas emissions]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/contents.html|title=IPCC Fourth Assessment Report: Climate Change 2007|last=Solomon, S., D. Qin, M. Manning, Z. Chen, M. Marquis, K.B. Averyt, M. Tignor and H.L. Miller (eds.)|first=|date=2007|website=Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change|access-date=}}</ref>
== Fossil fuels ==
=== Coal === [[File:Top 5 Coal Consumers.png|thumb|Coal consumption trends 1980–2012 in the top five coal-consuming countries ([[Energy Information Administration|US EIA]])]] [[File:Grand Junction Trip 92007 098.JPG|thumb|right|Coal-fired power plants provided 30% of consumed electricity in the United States in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eia.gov/electricity/monthly/epm_table_grapher.cfm?t=epmt_1_01|title=Electric Power Monthly - Table 1.1. Net Generation by Energy Source|date=2017-02-24|publisher=US Energy Information Administration|accessdate=2017-03-10}}</ref> This is the [[Carbon Power Plant|Castle Gate Plant]] near [[Helper, Utah]].]]
Coal is one of the largest sources of energy, supplying 28.6% percent of the world's primary energy in 2014 (equivalent to 3,917 [[Tonne of oil equivalent|Mtoe]]) according to the [[International Energy Agency]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/KeyWorld2016.pdf|title=Key World Energy Statistics|date=2016|website=International Energy Agency|access-date=}}</ref> Coal combustion accounted for 14,863 Mt of CO<sub>2</sub> emissions in 2014, which is equivalent to a 45.9% of fossil fuel emissions from combustion (excluding non-energy emissions).<ref name=":0" />
To decrease carbon emissions and thus possibly stop extreme climate change, some have called for coal to be phased out.<ref>Kharecha, P.A., and J.E. Hansen, [http://pubs.giss.nasa.gov/abstracts/2008/Kharecha_Hansen.html "Implications of "peak oil" for atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub> and climate,"] Global Biogeochem. Cycles, 22, GB3012, {{doi|10.1029/2007GB003142}}</ref><ref>* [http://www.houghtonmifflinbooks.com/catalog/titledetail.cfm?titleNumber=694238 ''Big Coal: The Dirty Secret Behind America's Energy Future'' by Jeff Goodell. 324 pages]</ref> Climatologist James E. Hansen said "We need a moratorium on coal now...with phase-out of existing plants over the next two decades."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/23/world/europe/23coal.html?_r=2&hp=&pagewanted=print&oref=slogin|title=Europe Turns Back to Coal, Raising Climate Fears|last=Rosenthal|first=Elizabeth|date=23 April 2008|work=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|quote=“We need a moratorium on coal now,” he added, “with phase-out of existing plants over the next two decades.”|accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref> According to a study published in [[Science (journal)|Science]] in 2017, coal has to be phased-out globally by about 2030, if the agreed 2 °C target is taken seriously.<ref>[[Johan Rockström]] et al.: ''A roadmap for rapid decarbonization''. In: Science. 355, 6331, 2017, pp. 1269–1271, {{DOI|10.1126/science.aah3443}}</ref>
Some nations have decreased their coal consumption thus far in the 21st century, the greatest reductions being in the United States (coal consumption reduced by 176 million metric tons per year over the period 2000–2012), Canada (reduced by 21 million tons per year) and Spain (20 million tons per year). Other nations have increased their coal consumption in the same period, led by China (increased 2,263 million metric tons per year in the period 2000–2012), India (increased 367 million tons per year), and South Korea (59 million tons per year). Worldwide, coal consumption increased 60% during the period 2000–2012.<ref>US Energy Information Administration, [http://www.eia.gov/cfapps/ipdbproject/IEDIndex3.cfm?tid=1&pid=1&aid=2 International statistics: coal consumption], 2012.</ref> As of 2012, 1200 new coal power plants were reportedly being planned worldwide, most of them in China and India.<ref>{{cite news | first=Damian | last=Carrington | url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2012/nov/20/coal-plants-world-resources-institute | title=More than 1,000 new coal plants being planned | newspaper=The Guardian, | date=19 November 2012}}</ref> In the 2011–2013 period, the [[OECD]] group of Western European countries has increased the use of coal, attributed largely to the low cost of coal and the high price of imported natural gas in Western Europe.<ref>{{cite web | publisher=US EIA | url=http://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail/2013-09-27/multiple-factors-push-western-europe-use-less-natural-gas-and-more | title=Multiple factors push Western Europe to use less natural gas and more coal | date=27 September 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927150527/http://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail/2013-09-27/multiple-factors-push-western-europe-use-less-natural-gas-and-more | archivedate=27 September 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> However, coal consumption has peaked in China in 2013 or 2014, depending on the data used and fell in 2015 by 3.6%, even though there was a growth of GDP of 6.9%.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Qi | first1 = Ye | display-authors = 1 | last2 = et al | year = 2016 | title = China's post-coal growth | url = | journal = [[Nature Geoscience]] | volume = 9| issue = | pages = 564–566| doi = 10.1038/ngeo2777 | bibcode = 2016NatGe...9..564Q}}</ref> After smaller increases, consumption remained below the prior peak by 2017.<ref>Qi Ye, Jiaqi Lu ([[Brookings Institute]]): China's coal comsumption has peaked[https://www.brookings.edu/2018/01/22/chinas-coal-consumption-has-peaked/], 20. Nov. 2018</ref> Worldwide coal consumption peaked in 2014 and declined in 2015 and 2016.<ref>http://www.bp.com/content/dam/bp/en/corporate/pdf/energy-economics/statistical-review-2017/bp-statistical-review-of-world-energy-2017-coal.pdf</ref>
According to [[Scientific American]], the average coal plant emits more than 100 times as much radiation per year than does a comparatively sized nuclear power plant, in the form of fly ash.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=coal-ash-is-more-radioactive-than-nuclear-waste|title=Coal Ash Is More Radioactive than Nuclear Waste: By burning away all the pesky carbon and other impurities, coal power plants produce heaps of radiation|date=2009-05-18|accessdate=2009-05-18}}</ref>
Some like the "coal advisory board" of the IEA believe that coal should not be phased out, considering that longer-term global economic growth cannot be achieved without adequate and affordable energy supplies, which will require continuing significant contributions from fossil fuels including coal. In this viewpoint, [[clean coal technology]] could reduce [[greenhouse gas]] emissions compatible with a low-emissions future.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.iea.org/ciab/papers/ciab.pdf|title=Reducing Greenhouse Gas Emissions - The Potential of Coal|website=Coal Industry Advisory Board/International Energy Agency|publisher=Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development/International Energy Agency|accessdate=28 July 2014}}</ref> Some environmentalists and climatologists support a phase-out and criticise clean coal as not a solution to [[climate change]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldwatch.org/node/5975|title=Clean Coal: Wave of the Future or Empty Rhetoric?|website=Worldwatch Institute|publisher=Worldwatch Institute|accessdate=28 July 2014}}</ref> Entrepreneurs promote improved regulations and modernised technology.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} Sometimes coal is replaced by natural gas, which has lower carbon emissions and produces less pollutants. However natural gas is also a fossil fuel, so a switch from coal to natural gas does not contribute to a fossil fuel phase-out.
{{As of|October 2018}}, 28 national governments, 19 sub-national governments and 28 organisations<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://poweringpastcoal.org/about/Powering_Past_Coal_Alliance_Members|title=Powering Past Coal Alliance members list|last=|first=|date=|website=poweringpastcoal.org|access-date=20 September 2018}}</ref> had become members of the [[Powering Past Coal Alliance]], each making a declaration to advance the transition away from unabated coal power generation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://poweringpastcoal.org/about/Powering_Past_Coal_Alliance_Declaration|title=Powering Past Coal Alliance declaration|last=|first=|date=|website=poweringpastcoal.org|access-date=20 September 2018}}</ref>
=== Oil === {{Unreferenced section|date=September 2018}} Oil is refined into [[fuel oil]], [[Diesel fuel|diesel]] and [[gasoline]]. The refined products are primarily for transportation by conventional cars, trucks, trains, planes and ships. Popular alternatives are [[human-powered transport]], [[public transport]], [[electric vehicles]], and [[biofuels]].
=== Natural gas === {{Main|Natural gas}} Although natural gas has about half the carbon intensity of coal it is also the single largest source of [[atmospheric methane]] in the United States. It is seen by many as a temporary "bridge fuel" to replace coal, but in turn to be replaced by renewable sources. However this "bridge fuel" is likely to significantly extend the use of fossil fuel as the average plant life is 35 years.<ref>https://energycenter.org/sites/default/files/docs/nav/policy/research-and-reports/Natural_Gas_Bridge_Fuel.pdf</ref> Gas consumption has tripled since 1971, and by 2015 it was generating half as much electricity as coal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/KeyNaturalGasTrends.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160417225701/https://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/KeyNaturalGasTrends.pdf|title=Key natural gas trends|year=2015|archive-date=2016-04-17|website=www.iea.org|page=6}}</ref> Since the consumption of gas is expected to grow an additional 10% by 2040, the phase out is likely to be many years in the future.<ref>https://www.iea.org/topics/naturalgas/</ref>
== Basis == The basis of phasing-out fossil fuels consists mainly of the projected lower cost of renewable sources of energy,<ref>http://www.irena.org/publications/2018/Jan/Renewable-power-generation-costs-in-2017</ref> but the avoidance of risks in health and [[mitigation of global warming]] are also important considerations.
=== Health === Using computer modeling he developed over 20 years, [[Mark Z. Jacobson]] has found that [[carbon]]aceous fuel [[particulate matter|soot emissions]] (which lead to respiratory illness, heart disease, and asthma) have resulted in 1.5 million premature deaths each year, mostly in the developing world where the non-fossil fuels wood and animal dung are used for cooking. Jacobson has also said that soot from diesel engines, coal-fired power plants, and burning wood is a "bigger cause of global warming than previously thought, and is the major cause of the rapid melting of the Arctic's sea ice".<ref name="dp">{{cite web | url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Scientists-say-soot-a-key-factor-in-warming-3180603.php#ixzz0v1KwN5yZ | title=Scientists say soot a key factor in warming | work=SFGate | date=28 July 2010 | accessdate=19 July 2016 | author=Perlman, David}}</ref>
In 2011, new evidence has emerged that there are considerable risks associated with traditional energy sources, and that major changes to the mix of energy technologies are needed:
{{Block quote|Several mining tragedies globally have underscored the human toll of the coal supply chain. New EPA initiatives targeting air toxics, coal ash, and effluent releases highlight the environmental impacts of coal and the cost of addressing them with control technologies. The use of fracking in natural gas exploration is coming under scrutiny, with evidence of groundwater contamination and greenhouse gas emissions. Concerns are increasing about the vast amounts of water used at coal-fired plants, particularly in regions of the country facing water shortages.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.civilsocietyinstitute.org/media/pdfs/Toward%20a%20Sustainable%20Future%2011-16-11.pdf |title=Toward a Sustainable Future for the U.S. Power Sector: Beyond Business as Usual 2011 |author=Synapse Energy Economics |date=16 November 2011 |work= }}</ref>}}
=== Global warming mitigation === {{See|Global warming}}In 2008, [[James E. Hansen|James Hansen]] and nine other scientists published a journal article titled "Target atmospheric {{co2}}: Where should humanity aim?" which calls for a complete phase-out of coal power by 2030.<ref name="hansen-etal-2008">{{cite journal | last2=Sato |first2=Makiko| last3=Kharecha |first3=Pushker| last4=Beerling|first4=David|last5=Berner|first5=Robert|last6=Masson-Delmotte|first6=Valerie|authorlink6=Valerie Masson-Delmotte | last7=Pagani |first7=Mark | last8=Raymo | first8=Maureen| last9=Royer | first9=Dana L | date=31 October 2008 | title=Target atmospheric {{co2}}: Where should humanity aim?|url=http://www.columbia.edu/~jeh1/2008/TargetCO2_20080407.pdf|journal=The Open Atmospheric Science Journal|volume=2|pages=217–231|arxiv=0804.1126|bibcode=2008OASJ....2..217H|doi=10.2174/1874282300802010217|access-date=2016-10-31|first1=James|last1=Hansen|first10=James C|last10=Zachos}} </ref>
More recently, Hansen has stated that continued [[opposition to nuclear power]] threatens humanity's ability to avoid dangerous climate change.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/11/03/world/nuclear-energy-climate-change-scientists-letter/|title=Top climate change scientists issue open letter to policy influencers - CNN.com|date=3 November 2013|author=By|work=CNN}}</ref> The letter, co-authored with other climate change experts declared "If we stay on the current path," he said, "those are the consequences we'll be leaving to our children. The best candidate to avoid that is nuclear power. It's ready now. We need to take advantage of it." and "Continued opposition to nuclear power threatens humanity's ability to avoid dangerous climate change."
Also in 2008, Pushker Kharecha and James Hansen published a peer-reviewed scientific study analyzing the effect of a coal phase-out on atmospheric [[carbon dioxide]] (CO<sub>2</sub>) levels.<ref>{{cite journal|year=2008|title=Implications of "peak oil" for atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub> and climate|url=http://pubs.giss.nasa.gov/abstracts/2008/Kharecha_Hansen.html|journal=Global Biogeochem. Cycles|volume=22|issue=3|pages=GB3012|arxiv=0704.2782|bibcode=2008GBioC..22.3012K|doi=10.1029/2007GB003142|author1=Kharecha, P.A.|author2=J.E. Hansen}}</ref> Their baseline mitigation scenario was a phaseout of global coal emissions by 2050. The authors describe the scenario as follows:
{{quote|The second scenario, labeled Coal Phase-out, is meant to approximate a situation in which developed countries freeze their CO<sub>2</sub> emissions from coal by 2012 and a decade later developing countries similarly halt increases in coal emissions. Between 2025 and 2050 it is assumed that both developed and developing countries will linearly phase out emissions of CO<sub>2</sub> from coal usage. Thus in Coal Phase-out we have global CO<sub>2</sub> emissions from coal increasing 2% per year until 2012, 1% per year growth of coal emissions between 2013 and 2022, flat coal emissions for 2023–2025, and finally a linear decrease to zero CO<sub>2</sub> emissions from coal in 2050. These rates refer to emissions to the atmosphere and do not constrain consumption of coal, provided the CO<sub>2</sub> is captured and sequestered. Oil and gas emissions are assumed to be the same as in the BAU [business as usual] scenario.}}
Kharecha and Hansen also consider three other mitigation scenarios, all with the same coal phase-out schedule but each making different assumptions about the size of oil and gas reserves and the speed at which they are depleted. Under the Business as Usual scenario, atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub> peaks at 563 parts per million (ppm) in the year 2100. Under the four coal phase-out scenarios, atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub> peaks at 422-446 ppm between 2045 and 2060 and declines thereafter. The key implications of the study are as follows: a phase-out of coal emissions is the most important remedy for mitigating human-induced global warming; actions should be taken toward limiting or stretching out the use of conventional oil and gas; and strict emissions-based constraints are needed for future use of unconventional fossil fuels such as [[methane hydrates]] and [[tar sands]].
=== Others === The impulse of renewable energy can create jobs through the construction of new power plants and the manufacturing of the equipment that they need, as could be seen in the case of Germany and the wind power industry.<ref name="Heinrichs 285–305">{{Cite journal|last=Heinrichs|first=Heidi Ursula|last2=Schumann|first2=Diana|last3=Vögele|first3=Stefan|last4=Biß|first4=Klaus Hendrik|last5=Shamon|first5=Hawal|last6=Markewitz|first6=Peter|last7=Többen|first7=Johannes|last8=Gillessen|first8=Bastian|last9=Gotzens|first9=Fabian|date=2017-05-01|title=Integrated assessment of a phase-out of coal-fired power plants in Germany|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0360544217303754|journal=Energy|volume=126|pages=285–305|doi=10.1016/j.energy.2017.03.017}}</ref>
== Studies about fossil fuel phase-out == In the [[Greenpeace]] and EREC's Energy (R)evolution scenario,<ref>[http://www.erec.org/documents/publications/energy-revolution.html?0=]{{dead link|date=December 2013}}</ref> the world would eliminate all fossil fuel use by 2090.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenpeace.org/international/campaigns/climate-change/energyrevolution |title=Energy Revolution |publisher=Greenpeace International |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.erec.org/fileadmin/erec_docs/Documents/Press_Releases/Press_release_Greenpeace_EREC__October_2008.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-10-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081029182526/http://www.erec.org/fileadmin/erec_docs/Documents/Press_Releases/Press_release_Greenpeace_EREC__October_2008.pdf |archivedate=29 October 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/channel/earth/dn15043-world-can-halt-fossil-fuel-use-by-2090.html |title=Science news and science jobs from New Scientist - New Scientist |publisher=Environment.newscientist.com |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref>
In December 2015, [[Greenpeace]] and [[Climate Action Network|Climate Action Network Europe]] released a report highlighting the need for an active phase-out of coal-fired generation across Europe. Their analysis derived from a database of 280 coal plants and included emissions data from official EU registries.<ref name="jones-and-gutmann-2015"> {{cite book | first1 = Dave | last1 = Jones | first2 = Kathrin | last2 = Gutmann | title = End of an era: why every European country needs a coal phase-out plan | date = December 2015 | publisher = Greenpeace and Climate Action Network Europe | location = London, UK and Brussels, Belgium | url = https://www.greenpeace.de/sites/www.greenpeace.de/files/publications/end-of-era-coal-phase-out-plan-20151204.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-14 }} </ref>
A September 2016 report by Oil Change International, concludes that the carbon emissions embedded in the coal, oil, and gas in currently working mines and fields, assuming that these run to the end of their working lifetimes, will take the world to just beyond the 2{{nnbsp}}°C limit contained in the 2015 [[Paris Agreement]] and even further from the 1.5{{nnbsp}}°C goal.<ref name="mathiesen-2016"> {{cite news | last = Mathiesen | first = Karl | title = Existing coal, oil and gas fields will blow carbon budget{{snd}} study | date = 23 September 2016 | work = The Guardian | location = London, UK | url = https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/sep/23/existing-coal-oil-and-gas-fields-will-blow-carbon-budget-study | access-date = 2016-09-28 }} </ref><ref name="turnbull-2016"> {{cite press release | first = David | last = Turnbull | title = Fossil Fuel Expansion Has Reached the Sky's Limit: Report | url = http://priceofoil.org/2016/09/22/release-fossil-fuel-expansion-has-reached-the-skys-limit-report/ | location = Washington DC, US | publisher = Oil Change International | date = 22 September 2016 | access-date = 2016-09-27 }} </ref><ref name="muttitt-2016"> <!-- see also: http://www.priceofoil.org --> {{cite book | first = Greg | last = Muttitt | title = The sky's limit: why the Paris climate goals require a managed decline of fossil fuel production | date = September 2016 | publisher = Oil Change International | location = Washington DC, US | url = http://priceofoil.org/content/uploads/2016/09/OCI_the_skys_limit_2016_FINAL_2.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-27 }} </ref> The report observes that "one of the most powerful climate policy levers is also the simplest: stop digging for more fossil fuels".<ref name="muttitt-2016"/>{{rp|5}}
In October 2016, the [[Overseas Development Institute]] (ODI) and 11 other [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]]s released a report on the impact of building new coal-fired power plants in countries where a significant proportion of the population lacks access to electricity. The report concludes that, on the whole, building coal-fired power plants does little to help the poor and may make them poorer. Moreover, wind and solar generation are beginning to challenge coal on cost.<ref name="nuccitelli-2016"> {{cite news | last = Nuccitelli | first = Dana | title = Coal doesn’t help the poor; it makes them poorer | work = The Guardian | location = London, United Kingdom | date = 31 October 2016 | issn = 0261-3077 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2016/oct/31/coal-doesnt-help-the-poor-it-makes-them-poorer | access-date = 2016-10-31 }} </ref><ref name="granoff-etal-2016-webpage"> {{cite web | first1 = Ilmi | last1 = Granoff | first2 = James Ryan | last2 = Hogarth | first3 = Sarah | last3 = Wykes | first4 = Alison | last4 = Doig | title = Beyond coal: scaling up clean energy to fight global poverty | date = October 2016 | work = Overseas Development Institute (ODI) | location = London, United Kingdom | url = https://www.odi.org/publications/10589-beyond-coal-scaling-clean-energy-fight-global-poverty | access-date = 2016-10-31 }} </ref><ref name="granoff-etal-2016-report"> {{cite book|url=https://www.odi.org/sites/odi.org.uk/files/resource-documents/10964.pdf|title=Beyond coal: Scaling up clean energy to fight global poverty — Position paper|last2=Hogarth|first2=James Ryan|last3=Wykes|first3=Sarah|last4=Doig|first4=Alison|date=October 2016|publisher=Overseas Development Institute (ODI)|location=London, United Kingdom|access-date=2016-10-31|first1=Ilmi|last1=Granoff}}</ref>
A 2018 study in Nature Energy, suggests that 10 countries in Europe could completely phase out coal-fired electricity generation with their current infrastructure, whilst the United States and Russia could phase out at least 30%.<ref name="wilson-and-staffell-2018"> {{Cite journal|last=Wilson|first=IAG|last2=Staffell|first2=I|date=2018|title=Rapid fuel switching from coal to natural gas through effective carbon pricing|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41560-018-0109-0|journal=Nature Energy|volume=3|pages=365–372|doi=10.1038/s41560-018-0109-0|bibcode=2018NatEn...3..365W}} </ref>
== Challenges of fossil fuel phase-out == The phase-out of fossil fuels involves many challenges, and one of them is the reliance that currently the world has on them. In 2014, fossil fuels provided 81.1% of the [[primary energy consumption]] of the world, with approximately 11,109 Mtoe. This number is composed by 4,287 Mtoe of oil consumption; 3,918 Mtoe of coal consumption, and 2,904 Mtoe of natural gas consumption.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/KeyWorld2016.pdf|title=Key World Energy Statistics|last=|first=|date=2016|website=International Energy Agency|access-date=}}</ref>
Fossil fuel phase-out can lead to an increment in electricity prices, because of the new investments needed to replace their share in the electricity mix with alternative energy sources.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Green|first=R|last2=Staffell|first2=I|date=2016|title=Electricity in Europe: exiting fossil fuels?|url=https://academic.oup.com/oxrep/article-pdf/32/2/282/7298756/grw003.pdf|journal=Oxford Review of Economic Policy|volume=32|issue=2|pages=282-303|doi=10.1093/oxrep/grw003}}</ref> Another cause to increasing electricity price comes from the need to import the electricity that can't be generated nationally.<ref>Yilmaz, H. Ü., Bchini, Q., Keles, D., Hartel, R., Fichtner, W., Mikulić, M., & Jakšić, D. (2016). Impacts of a UK and German coal phase-out on the electricity mix and CO 2 emissions in Europe. ''Insight Energy'', (April). Retrieved from <nowiki>http://www.insightenergy.org/system/publication_files/files/000/000/045/original/HET14_Coal_Phaseout_Final.pdf?1474967926</nowiki></ref>
Another impact of a phase-out of fossil fuels is in the employment. In the case of employments in the fossil fuel industry, a phase-out is logically undesired, therefore, people in the industry will usually oppose any measures that put their industries under scrutiny.<ref name="Heinrichs 285–305"/> Endre Tvinnereim and Elisabeth Ivarsflaten studied the relationship between employment in the fossil fuel industry with the support to climate change policies. They proposed that one opportunity for displaced drilling employments in the fossil fuel industry could be in the geothermal energy industry. This was suggested as a result of their conclusion: people and companies in the fossil fuel industry will likely oppose measures that endanger their employments, unless they have other stronger alternatives.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tvinnereim|first=Endre|last2=Ivarsflaten|first2=Elisabeth|date=2016-09-01|title=Fossil fuels, employment, and support for climate policies|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421516302828|journal=Energy Policy|volume=96|pages=364–371|doi=10.1016/j.enpol.2016.05.052}}</ref> This can be extrapolated to political interests, that can push against the phase-out of fossil fuels initiative. One example is how the vote of [[United Stats|US]] Congress members is related to the preeminence of fossil fuel industries in their respective states.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cragg|first=Michael I.|last2=Zhou|first2=Yuyu|last3=Gurney|first3=Kevin|last4=Kahn|first4=Matthew E.|date=2013-04-01|title=Carbon Geography: The Political Economy of Congressional Support for Legislation Intended to Mitigate Greenhouse Gas Production|ssrn=2225690}}</ref>
== Legislation and initiatives to phase out coal ==
=== Major economies === In 8 June 2015, several newspapers ran an article wrote that the leaders of the [[Group of Seven]] (or G7, consisting of [[Canada]], [[France]], [[Germany]], [[Italy]], [[Japan]], the [[United Kingdom]], and the [[United States]]) agreed to phase-out fossil fuel use by 2100,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jun/08/g7-leaders-agree-phase-out-fossil-fuel-use-end-of-century|title=G7 leaders agree to phase out fossil fuel use by end of century|last=Connolly|first=Kate|date=2015-06-08|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-04-30|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/ec2c365a-0ddf-11e5-aa7b-00144feabdc0|title=G7 leaders agree to phase out fossil fuels|last=Clark|first=Pilita|date=8 June 2015|work=Financial Times|access-date=|last2=Wagstyl|first2=Stefan|month=}}</ref> as part of the efforts to keep global temperature increase under 2°C. This was done as a prelude for the United Nations Climate Change Conference (a.k.a. [[COP 21]]) hosted in Paris, on December of the same year.
=== Australia === [[File:Graph RE Australia 2010.svg|thumb|Electricity generation from renewable sources in Australia in 2010]]
The [[Australian Greens]] party have proposed to phase out coal power stations. The NSW Greens proposed an immediate moratorium on coal-fired power stations and want to end all coal mining and [[coal industry subsidies]]. The Australian Greens and the [[Australian Labor Party]] also oppose nuclear power. The Federal Government and Victorian State Government want to modify existing coal-fired power stations into clean coal power stations.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} The Federal Labor government extended the [[Mandatory Renewable Energy Target#Australia|mandatory renewable energy target]]s, an initiative to ensure that new sources of electricity are more likely to be from wind power, solar power and other sources of [[renewable energy in Australia]]. [[Australia]] is one of the largest consumers of coal per capita, and also the largest exporter. The proposals are strongly opposed by industry, unions<ref>[http://www.australian-options.org.au/issues/options_53/article_colley.php Australian Options Magazine, CFMEU on coal phase out] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320100225/http://www.australian-options.org.au/issues/options_53/article_colley.php |date=20 March 2012 }}</ref> and the main Opposition Party in Parliament (now forming the party in government after the September 2013 election).
=== Canada === In 2005, Canada annually burned 60 million tons of coal, mainly for electrical power, increasing by 15 percent annually.
In November 2016, Canada announced plans to phase-out coal-fired electricity generation by 2030.<ref name="the-guardian-2016"> {{cite news | title = Canada plans to phase out coal-powered electricity by 2030 | date = 21 November 2016 | work = The Guardian | location = London, United Kingdom | issn = 0261-3077 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/nov/21/canada-coal-electricity-phase-out-2030 | access-date = 2016-11-22 }} </ref>
Beginning in 2005, [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] planned coal phase-out legislation.<ref>[http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20050216005791/en/Ontarios-Coal-Phase-out-Drastic-Consequences-Thinking-Companies#.Uv-cnP0-vCE Ontario's Coal Phase-out Will Have Drastic Consequences, Say The Thinking Companies]. 16 February 2005</ref> Ontario annually consumed 15 million tons of coal in large power plants to supplement nuclear power. [[Nanticoke Generating Station]] was a major source of air pollution, and Ontario suffered "smog days" during the summer.{{citation needed|date = February 2014}} In 2007, Ontario's Liberal government committed to phasing out all coal generation in the province by 2014. Premier Dalton McGuinty said, "By 2030 there will be about 1,000 more new coal-fired generating stations built on this planet. There is only one place in the world that is phasing out coal-fired generation and we're doing that right here in Ontario."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20070618/ont_coal_plants_070618/20070618 |title=Ont. Liberals promise to close coal plants by 2014 |publisher=CTV News |accessdate=2013-12-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090805111218/http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20070618/ont_coal_plants_070618/20070618 |archivedate=5 August 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The Ontario Power Authority projects that in 2014, with no coal generation, the largest sources of electrical power in the province will be nuclear (57 percent), hydroelectricity (25 percent), and natural gas (11 percent).<ref>Ontario Power Authority, [https://web.archive.org/web/20130716053358/http://www.powerauthority.on.ca/power-planning/long-term-energy-plan-2013 Long-Term Energy Plan 2013], module 3, 2014.</ref> In April 2014 [[Ontario electricity policy|Ontario Canada]] was the first jurisdiction in North America to eliminate coal in electricity generation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.ontario.ca/mei/en/2014/04/creating-cleaner-air-in-ontario-1.html|title=Creating Cleaner Air in Ontario|publisher=}}</ref> The final coal plant in Ontario, [[Thunder Bay Generating Station]], stopped burning coal in April 2014.<ref>http://www.opg.com/news-and-media/news-releases/Documents/140415TBGSBurnsLastCoal.pdf</ref>
=== China === There are currently no plans to phase out coal burning power stations in the [[People's Republic of China]] on the national level.
China's exceedingly high energy demand has pushed the demand for relatively cheap coal-fired power. Each week, another 2 GW of coal-fired power is put online in China. Coal supplies about 80% of China's energy needs today, and that ratio is expected to continue, even as overall power usage grows rapidly. Serious air quality deterioration has resulted from the massive use of coal and many Chinese cities suffer severe smog events.{{citation needed|date=May 2010}}
As a consequence the region of Beijing has decided to phase out all its coal-fired power generation by the end of 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.platts.com/latest-news/electric-power/singapore/chinas-beijing-city-to-abolish-coal-fired-power-27490804|title=China's Beijing city to abolish coal-fired power plants by end 2014 - Electric Power - Platts News Article & Story|website=www.platts.com}}</ref> {{Update inline|date=November 2016}}
In 2009, China had 172 GW of installed hydro capacity the largest in the world, producing 16% of China's electricity, the Eleventh Five-Year Plan has set a 300 GW target for 2020. China built the world's largest power plant of any kind, the [[Three Gorges Dam]].
In addition to the huge investments in coal power, China has 32<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iaea.org/PRIS/CountryStatistics/CountryDetails.aspx?current=CN |title=PRIS - Country Details |publisher=Iaea.org |accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref> reactors under construction, the highest number in the world.
Analysis in 2016, showed that China's coal consumption appears to have peaked in 2014.<ref name="carrington-2016">{{cite news | first = Damian | last = Carrington | title = China's coal peak hailed as turning point in climate change battle | date = 25 July 2016 | newspaper = The Guardian | url = https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/jul/25/china-coal-peak-hailed-turning-point-climate-change-battle | access-date = 2016-07-25}}</ref><ref name="qi-etal-2016">{{cite journal | first1 = Ye |last1 = Qi | first2 = Nicholas |last2 = Stern | first3 = Tong | last3 = Wu | first4 = Jiaqi |last4 = Lu | first5 = Fergus | last5 = Green | author-link2 = Nicholas Stern, Baron Stern of Brentford | title = China's post-coal growth | date = 25 July 2016 | journal = Nature Geoscience | doi = 10.1038/ngeo2777 | volume=9 | pages=564–566| bibcode = 2016NatGe...9..564Q }}</ref>
=== European Union === In July 2014, [[Climate Action Network|CAN Europe]], [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF European Policy Office]], HEAL, [[European Environmental Bureau|EEB]] and [[Climate-Alliance Germany]] published a report calling for the decommissioning of the thirty most polluting coal-fired power plants in Europe.<ref name="gutmann-etal-2014"> {{cite book | first1 = Kathrin | last1 = Gutmann | first2 = Julia | last2 = Huscher | first3 = Darek | last3 = Urbaniak | first4 = Adam | last4 = White | first5 = Christian | last5 = Schaible | first6 = Mona | last6 = Bricke | title = Europe's dirty 30: how the EU's coal-fired power plants are undermining its climate efforts | date = July 2014 | publisher = CAN Europe, WWF European Policy Office, HEAL, the EEB, and Climate-Alliance Germany | location = Brussels, Belgium | url = http://awsassets.panda.org/downloads/dirty_30_report_finale.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-22 }} </ref>
==== Denmark ==== As part of their Climate policy Plan, Denmark stated that it will phase out oil for heating purposes and coal by 2030. Additionally, their goal is to supply a 100% of their electricity and heating needs with renewable energy five years later (i.e. 2035).<ref>The Danish Government. (2013). ''The Danish Climate Policy Plan: Towards a low carbon society''. The Ministry of climate, energy and building. Copenhagen. Retrieved from <nowiki>https://stateofgreen.com/files/download/386</nowiki></ref>
==== France ==== [[File:Emmanuel Macron (2017-05-29, cropped).jpg|thumb|On 30 December 2017, [[Emmanuel Macron]] signed a law planning the end of fossil-fuel extraction in French territories.]]
In December 2017, to fight against [[global warming]], France adopted a law banning new [[fossil fuel]] exploitation projects and closing current ones by 2040 in all of its territories. France thus became the first country to programme the end of [[fossil fuel]] exploitation.<ref>[[Agence France-Presse]], [https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/dec/20/france-bans-fracking-and-oil-extraction-in-all-of-its-territories "France bans fracking and oil extraction in all of its territories "], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 20 December 2017 (page visited on 30 December 2017).</ref><ref>{{fr}} [http://www.rts.ch/info/monde/9211145-la-france-devient-le-premier-pays-a-programmer-la-fin-des-hydrocarbures.html "La France devient le premier pays à programmer la fin des hydrocarbures"], [[Radio télévision suisse]], 30 December 2017 (page visited on 30 December 2017).</ref>
==== Germany ==== [[File:Ende Gelaende Einzug Tagebau Tag 1.jpg|thumb|3,500-4,000 [[environmental activist]]s blocking a coal mine to [[Climate change mitigation|limit climate change]] ([[Ende Gelände 2016]]).]]
[[Hard coal]] mining has long been subsidized in Germany, reaching a peak of €6.7{{nbsp}}billion in 1996 and dropping to €2.7{{nbsp}}billion in 2005 due to falling output. These subsidies represent a burden on public finances and imply a substantial [[opportunity cost]], diverting funds away from other, more beneficial public investments.<ref name="frondel-etal-2007"> {{cite journal | first1 = Manuel | last1 = Frondel | first2 = Rainer | last2 = Kambeck | first3 = Christoph M | last3 = Schmidt | title = Hard coal subsidies: a never-ending story? | year = 2007 | journal = Energy Policy | volume = 35 | number = 7 | pages = 3807–3814 | doi = 10.1016/j.enpol.2007.01.019 }}</ref>
In 2007, Germany announced plans to phase out hard coal-industry subsidies by 2018, a move which is expected to end hard coal mining in Germany. {{update after|2018|01|01}}<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/feeds/afx/2007/01/30/afx3374339.html |work=Forbes |title=Germany to shut down coal mines in 2018 |date=30 January 2007 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/0,1518,463172,00.html |title=End of an Industrial Era: Germany to Close its Coal Mines |publisher=Spiegel Online |date=2007-01-30 |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated3">{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/low/business/6309841.stm | work=BBC News | title=German plan to close coal mines | date=29 January 2007 | accessdate=2 May 2010}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated4">{{cite web|last=Gonzalez |first=David |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/08/08/business/EU-FIN-ECO-Germany-Coal-Mining.php |title=The New York Times - Breaking News, World News & Multimedia |publisher=International Herald Tribune |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated5">{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/0,1518,463174,00.html |title=The World From Berlin: Good Riddance to Coal Mining |publisher=Spiegel Online |date=2007-01-30 |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref> This exit is later than the EU-mandated end by 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/germany-stays-firm-on-plan-to-scrap-coal-subsidies-in-2018/a-6243150|title=Germany stays firm on plan to scrap coal subsidies in 2018 |date=17 November 2010|publisher=Deutsche Welle|website=dw.com}}</ref> Solar and wind are major sources of energy and renewable energy generation, around 15% as of December 2013,<ref>{{cite web|author=www.kenovate.com |url=http://www.rncos.com/Blog/2009/02/Germany-targets-47-Renewable-Energy-Production-by-2020.html |title=Germany targets 47% Renewable Energy Production by 2020 |publisher=Rncos.com |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref> and growing. Coal is still the largest source of power in Germany.
In 2007, [[Chancellor of Germany|German Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]] and her party agreed to legislation to phase out Germany's hard coal mining sector. That does not mean that they support phasing out coal in general. There were plans to build about 25 new plants in the coming years. Most German coal power plants were built in the 1960s, and have a low energy efficiency. Public sentiment against coal power plants is growing and the construction or planning of some plants has been stopped.<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref name="autogenerated2"/><ref name="autogenerated3"/><ref name="autogenerated4"/><ref name="autogenerated5"/> A number are under construction and still being built. No concrete plan is in place to reduce coal-fired electricity generation. As of October 2015, the remaining coal plants still under planning include: Niederaussem, Profen, and Stade. The coal plants currently under construction include: Mannheim, Hamm D, Datteln, and Willhelmshaven. Between 2012 and 2015, six new plants went online. All of these plants are 600–1800  [[Megawatt|MW]]<sub>e</sub>.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://energytransition.de/2015/10/the-demise-of-coal-in-germany-and-globally/|title=The demise of coal in Germany and globally|date=15 October 2015|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2014, Germany's coal consumption dropped for the first time, having risen each year since the low during the 2009 recession.<ref name="bp-statistical-review-2015"> {{cite book | title = BP Statistical Review of World Energy 2015 | publisher = BP | location = London, UK | url = https://www.bp.com/content/dam/bp/pdf/energy-economics/statistical-review-2015/bp-statistical-review-of-world-energy-2015-full-report.pdf | access-date = 2016-10-07 }} </ref>
A 2014 study, found that coal is not making a comeback in Germany, as is sometimes claimed. Rather renewables have more than offset the nuclear facilities that have been shutdown as a result of Germany's [[Nuclear power phase-out#Germany|nuclear phase-out]] (''Atomausstieg''). Hard coal plants now face financial stringency as their operating hours are cut back by the market. But in contrast, [[lignite]]-fired generation is in a safe position until the {{nowrap|mid-2020s}} unless government policies change. To phase-out coal, Germany should seek to strength the emissions trading system ([[European Union Emission Trading Scheme|EU-ETS]]), consider a carbon tax, promote [[efficient energy use|energy efficiency]], and strengthen the use of natural gas as a bridge fuel.<ref name="jungjohann-and-morris-2014"> {{cite book | last1 = Jungjohann | first1 = Arne | last2 = Morris | first2 = Craig | title = The German coal conundrum | date = June 2014 | publisher = Heinrich Böll Stiftung | location = Washington, DC, US | url = http://www.indiaenvironmentportal.org.in/files/file/German_Coal_Conundrum.pdf | access-date = 2016-10-07 }} </ref>
In 2016, the German government and affected [[lignite]] power plant operators [[:de:Mitteldeutsche Braunkohlengesellschaft|Mibrag]], [[RWE]], and [[Vattenfall]] reached an understanding (''Verständigung'') on the transfer of lignite power plant units into security standby (''Überführung von Braunkohlekraftwerksblöcken in die Sicherheitsbereitschaft''). As a result, eight lignite-fired power plants are to be mothballed and later closed, with the first plant scheduled to cease operation in October 2016 and the last in October 2019. The affected operators will receive state compensation for foregone profits. The [[European Commission]] has declared government plans to use €1.6{{nbsp}}billion of public financing for this purpose to be in line with EU [[state aid]] rules.<ref name="german-energy-blog-2016"> {{cite web | title = EU Commission Approves State Aid for Closure of Lignite-Fired Power Plants | date = 31 May 2016 | website = German Energy Blog | url = http://www.germanenergyblog.de/?p=19921 | access-date = 2016-07-28 }}</ref>
A 2016 study, found that the phase-out of lignite in [[Lusatia]] (''Lausitz'') by 2030 can be financed by future owner [[Energetický a průmyslový holding|EPH]] in a manner that avoids taxpayer involvement. Instead, liabilities covering decommissioning and land rehabilitation could be paid by EPH directly into a foundation, perhaps run by the public company [[:de:Lausitzer und Mitteldeutsche Bergbau-Verwaltungsgesellschaft|LMBV]]. The study calculates the necessary provisions at €2.6{{nbsp}}billion.<ref name="ieefa-2016"> {{cite web | title = IEEFA Europe: Blueprint for a Lignite Phase-Out in Germany | work = Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis | date = 22 September 2016 | url = http://ieefa.org/ieefa-europe-blueprint-lignite-phase-germany/ | access-date = 2016-09-23 }} </ref><ref name="wynn-and-julve-2016"> {{cite book | first1 = Gerard | last1 = Wynn | first2 = Javier | last2 = Julve | title = A Foundation-Based Framework for Phasing Out German Lignite in Lausitz | date = September 2016 | publisher = Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis (IEEFA) | url = http://ieefa.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/A-Foundation-Based-Framework-for-Phasing-Out-German-Lignite-in-Lausitz_September2016.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-23 }} </ref>
In November 2016, the German utility [[Evonik Industries#Energy Business Area|STEAG]] announced it will be decommissioning five coal-fired generating units in [[North Rhine-Westphalia]] and [[Saarland]] due to low wholesale electricity prices.<ref name="clew-2016a"> {{cite news | title = Utility to shut down five coal plants | date = 3 November 2016 | work = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/german-energy-use-stable-energiewendes-sobering-results/utility-shut-down-five-coal-plants | access-date = 2016-11-03 }} </ref><ref name="handelsblatt-2016"> {{cite news | title = Steag: Energiekonzern schaltet fünf Kohlekraftwerke ab | trans-title = Steag: Energy corporation switches off five coal-fired power plants | language = German | date = 2 November 2016 | newspaper = Handelsblatt | location = Düsseldorf, Germany | url = https://www.handelsblatt.com/unternehmen/industrie/steag-energiekonzern-schaltet-fuenf-kohlekraftwerke-ab/14784534.html | access-date = 2016-11-03 }} </ref>
A coal phase-out for Germany is implied in Germany's [[German Climate Action Plan 2050|Climate Action Plan 2050]], environment minister [[Barbara Hendricks (politician)|Barbara Hendricks]] said in an interview on 21{{nbsp}}November 2016. "If you read the Climate Action Plan carefully, you will find that the exit from coal-fired power generation is the immanent consequence of the energy sector target.{{nbsp}}... By 2030{{nbsp}}... half of the coal-fired power production must have ended, compared to 2014", she said.<ref name="clew-2016b"> {{cite news | title = Coal exit is in the Climate Action Plan | date = 21 November 2016 | work = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/climate-plan-implies-coal-exit-minister-merkel-seeks-4th-term/coal-exit-climate-action-plan | access-date = 2016-11-22 }} </ref><ref name="goetze-and-schwarz-2016"> {{cite news | first1 = Susanne | last1 = Götze | first2 = Susanne | last2 = Schwarz | title = Kohleausstieg steht im Klimaschutzplan | trans-title = Coal exit is in the Climate Action Plan | language = German | date = 21 November 2016 | work = klimaretter.info | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://www.klimaretter.info/politik/hintergrund/22297-hendricks-kohleausstieg-steht-im-klimaschutzplan | access-date = 2016-11-22 }} </ref>
Plans to cut down the ancient [[Hambach Forest]] to extend the [[Hambach open pit mine]] in 2018 have resulted in massive protests. On 5 Oct, 2018 a German court ruled against the further destruction of the forest for mining purposes. The ruling states, the court needs more time to reconsider the complaint. Angela Merkel, the chancellor of Germany, welcomed the court's ruling. The forest is located approximately 29 km km west of the city center of Cologne (specifically Cologne Cathedral).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/10/05/europe/germany-hambach-forest-court-intl/index.html|title=Hambach Forest clearance halted by German court|last=CNN|first=Laura Smith-Spark,|work=CNN|access-date=2018-11-16}}</ref>
==== Netherlands ==== On 22 September 2016, the Dutch parliament voted for a 55% cut in {{CO2}} emissions by 2030, a move which would require the closure of the country's five coal-fired power plants. The vote is not binding on the government however.<ref name="neslen=2016"> {{cite news | first = Arthur | last = Neslen | title = Dutch parliament votes to close down country's coal industry | date = 23 September 2016 | newspaper = The Guardian | location = London, UK | url = https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/sep/23/dutch-parliament-votes-to-close-down-countrys-coal-industry | access-date = 2016-09-23 }} </ref>
==== Spain ==== In October 2018, the [[Sánchez government]] and Spanish [[Labour union]]s settled an agreement to close ten [[Coal mining#SPain|Spanish coal mines]] at the end of 2018. The government pre-engaged to spend 250 million Euro to pay for early retirements, occupational retraining and structural change. In 2018, about 2.3 per cent of the electric energy produced in Spain was produced in [[coal-burning power plant]]s.<ref>theguardian.com 26. October 2018: [https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/oct/26/spain-to-close-most-coal-mines-after-striking-250m-deal ''Spain to close most coal mines after striking €250m deal'']</ref>
=== Sweden === Sweden is constructing hydrogen-based pilot steel plant to replace coke and coal usage in steel production.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/coal/sweden-starts-construction-on-fossil-fuel-free-steel-plant/64675998 |title=Sweden starts construction on fossil fuel-free steel plant |accessdate=21 June 2018 }}</ref> Once this technology is commercialized with the [[Hydrogen production|hydrogen generated]] from renewable energy sources ([[biogas]] or electricity), the carbon foot print of steel production would reduce drastically.<ref name=cf>{{cite web|url=http://www.solarpaces.org/new-iea-report/ |title=New IEA Report: Renewable Energy for Industry |accessdate=21 June 2018 }}</ref>
=== India === [[File:India Coal Production.png|thumb|Coal Production in [[India]], with a 1959-2020 axis (appears to end at 2012)]] India is the third largest consumer of coal in the world. India's federal energy minister is planning to stop importing thermal coal by 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/economy/thermal-coal-imports-must-be-stopped-goyal/article7209584.ece|title=Thermal coal imports will stop by 2017: Goyal|first=Our|last=Bureau|date=15 May 2015|publisher=}}</ref> The annual report of India's Power Ministry has a plan to grow power by about 80 GW as part of their 11th 5-year plan, and 79% of that growth will be in fossil fuel–fired power plants, primarily coal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://powermin.nic.in/indian_electricity_scenario/pdf/Annual_Report_2008-09_English.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-04-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718131617/http://powermin.nic.in/indian_electricity_scenario/pdf/Annual_Report_2008-09_English.pdf |archivedate=18 July 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> India plans four new "ultra mega" coal-fired power plants as part of that growth, each 4000 MW in capacity. {{As of|2015}}, there are six nuclear reactors under construction. In the first half of 2016, the amount of coal-fired generating capacity in pre-construction planning in India fell by 40,000 MW, according to results released by the Global Coal Plant Tracker.<ref>Alister Doyle, [https://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-coal-idUSKCN11C2N4 "Global coal power plans fall in 2016, led by China, India: study,"] Reuters, 6 September 2016</ref> In June 2016, India's Ministry of Power stated that no further power plants would be required in the next three years, and "any thermal power plant that has yet to begin construction should back off."<ref>[http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/india-wont-need-extra-power-plants-for-next-three-years-says-government-report/articleshow/52545715.cms "India won't need extra power plants for next three years, says government report,"] The Economic Times, 2 June 2016</ref>
In cement production, carbon neutral biomass is being used to replace coal for reducing carbon foot print drastically.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zkg.de/en/artikel/zkg_Geocycle_secures_biomass_needs_from_local_farmers_in_India_3116884.html |title=Lafargeholcim - Geocycle secures biomass needs from local farmers in India |accessdate=21 June 2018 }}</ref><ref name=cf/>
=== New Zealand === In October 2007, the [[Helen Clark|Clark]] [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour]] government introduced a 10{{nbsp}}year moratorium on new fossil fuel thermal power generation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.powergenworldwide.com/index/display/articledisplay/308764/articles/power-engineering/industry-news/new-zealand-issues-ten-year-ban-on-new-thermal-power-plants.html |title=New Zealand issues ten-year ban on new thermal power plants |work=Power-Gen Worldwide |publisher=[[PennWell Corporation]] |date=2007-10-11 |accessdate=2011-01-07 }}</ref> The ban was limited to state-owned utilities, although an extension to the private sector was considered. The [[Fifth National Government of New Zealand|new government]] under MP [[John Key]] ([[New Zealand National Party|NZNP]]) [[New Zealand general election, 2008|elected in November 2008]] repealed this legislation.{{Citation needed|date=August 2015}}
In 2014, almost 80 per cent of the electricity produced in [[New Zealand]] was from [[sustainable energy]].<ref>{{cite news | website=www.sciencealert.com | date=10 August 2015 | url=http://www.sciencealert.com/new-zealand-will-shut-down-its-last-large-coal-fired-power-stations-in-2018 | title=New Zealand will shut down its last large coal-fired power generators in 2018 }}</ref> On 6 August 2015, [[Genesis Energy Limited]] announced that it would close its two last [[Fossil-fuel power station|coal-fired power stations]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.asx.com.au/asxpdf/20150806/pdf/430b9m38rq42jm.pdf | title=Market release: GNE announces timetable to end coal-fired generation in New Zealand}}</ref>
=== South Africa === As of 2007, South Africa's power sector is the 8th highest global emitter of CO<sub>2</sub>.<ref>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/11/071114163448.htm</ref> In 2005/2006, 77% of South Africa's energy demand was directly met by coal,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dme.gov.za/energy/coal.stm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091202053007/http://www.dme.gov.za/energy/coal.stm |archivedate=2 December 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref> and when current projects come online, this ratio will increase in the near term.
There are no plans to phase out coal-fired power plants in South Africa, and indeed, the country is investing in building massive amounts of new coal-fired capacity to meet power demands, as well as modernizing the existing coal-fired plants to meet environmental requirements.
On April 6, 2010, the World Bank approved a $3.75B loan to South Africa to support the construction of the world's 4th largest coal-fired plant, at Medupi.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/environment/article7088297.ece | work=[[The Times]] | location=London | title=Britain may block World Bank loan for coal plant in South Africa | first=Ben | last=Webster | date=April 6, 2010 | accessdate=May 2, 2010}}</ref> The proposed World Bank loan includes a relatively small amount{{snd}} $260 million{{snd}} for wind and solar power.
Rated at 4800 GW, [[Medupi Power Station]] would join other mammoth coal-fired power plants already in operation in the country, namely [[Kendal Power Station]] (4100 GW), [[Majuba Power Station]] (4100 GW), and [[Matimba Power Station]] (4000 GW), as well as a similar-capacity [[Kusile Power Station]], at 4800 GW, currently under construction. Kusile is expected to come online in stages, starting in 2012, while Medupi is expected to first come online in 2013, with full capacity available by 2017. These schedules are provisional, and may change.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
Since 2008, South Africa's government started funding [[solar water heating]] installations. As of January 2016, there have been 400 000 domestic installations in total, with free-of-charge installation of low-pressure solar water heaters for low-cost homes or low-income households which have access to the electricity grid, while other installations are subsidised.<ref>http://www.ee.co.za/article/solar-water-heater-rollout-programme-gains-momentum.html</ref>
=== United Kingdom === [[Ed Miliband]] ([[Secretary of State for Energy and Climate Change|energy secretary]] from 3 October 2008{{snd}} 11 May 2010) announced that no new coal-fired power stations will be built in Britain from 2009 onwards unless they capture and bury at least 25% of greenhouse gases immediately and 100% by 2025 although at the time this was a statement of intent rather than something he was able to enforce.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2009/apr/23/clean-coal-energy-policy | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=John | last=Vidal | title=Clean coal push marks reversal of UK energy policy | date=April 23, 2009}}</ref>
[[Chris Huhne]] (energy secretary from 12 May 2010{{snd}} 5 February 2012) has confirmed that the legislation required to allow his office to enforce [[Emission standard#UK|emissions standards]] are proceeding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessgreen.com/bg/news/1806551/huhne-promises-coal-plants-ccs |title=Huhne promises no more coal plants without CCS |publisher=BusinessGreen |date=17 Aug 2010 |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref>
The UK is also subject to the EU's [[Large Combustion Plant Directive]] covering non-CO2 emissions which is expected to bring many older plants to a close over the next few years as they are too expensive to upgrade.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.defra.gov.uk/environment/quality/industrial/eu-international/lcpd/ |title=Large Combustion Plant Directive « Industrial emissions |publisher=Defra.gov.uk |accessdate=2013-12-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120424052427/http://www.defra.gov.uk/environment/quality/industrial/eu-international/lcpd/ |archivedate=24 April 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
[[Amber Rudd]] (energy secretary from 11 May 2015) announced on 18 November 2015 that all coal-fired power stations would close by 2025. This will not be a complete phase out of fossil fuels because gas-fired power stations will continue to provide some [[firm power]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/energy/12001752/UK-coal-plants-must-close-by-2025-Amber-Rudd-to-announce.html|title=UK coal plants must close by 2025, Amber Rudd announces|publisher=}}</ref>
The closure of the last coal power station in March 2016 ended coal-fired [[Energy policy of Scotland|power production in Scotland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-edinburgh-east-fife-35882883|title=Longannet switch-off ends coal-fired power production in Scotland|date=24 March 2016|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref>
=== United States === In 2017, fossil fuels provided 81 percent of the energy consumed in the United States, down from 86 percent in 2000.<ref>US Energy Information Administration, [https://www.eia.gov/totalenergy/data/monthly/pdf/sec1_7.pdf Primary energy consumption by source], accessed 5 Apr. 2018</ref>
{{US electricity generation by coal table}} [[File:Estimated Effect of Carbon Tax in US.png|left|thumb|Estimated effect of a [[carbon tax]] on sources of United States electrical generation (US Energy Information Administration)]] [[File:US Total Energy 1949-2011.png|thumb|Total energy consumption in the US by source: comparing fossil fuels with nuclear and renewable energy]] [[File:US Electricity Fossil Fuels vs Others.png|thumb|US electrical generation: fossil fuels vs. nuclear and renewable energy]]
In 2007, 154 new coal-fired plants were on the drawing board in 42 states.<ref>[https://www.wired.com/techbiz/media/news/2006/10/71952 Eco Concern: Coal Plant Boom] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101214223405/http://www.wired.com/techbiz/media/news/2006/10/71952 |date=14 December 2010 }}</ref> By 2012, that had dropped to 15, mostly due to new rules limiting mercury emissions, and limiting carbon emissions to 1,000 pounds of CO<sub>2</sub> per megawatt-hour of electricity produced.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303404704577307524051798192|title=EPA Proposes CO|author=Keith Johnson in Washington, Rebecca Smith in San Francisco and Kris Maher in Pittsburgh|date=28 March 2012|work=WSJ}}</ref>
In July 2013, US Secretary of Energy [[Ernest Moniz]] outlined Obama administration policy on fossil fuels:
{{Block quote|In the last four years, we’ve more than doubled renewable energy generation from wind and solar power. However, coal and other fossil fuels still provide 80 percent of our energy, 70 percent of our electricity, and will be a major part of our energy future for decades. That’s why any serious effort to protect our kids from the worst effects of climate change must also include developing, demonstrating and deploying the technologies to use our abundant fossil fuel resources as cleanly as possible.<ref>Ernest Moritz, [http://energy.gov/articles/excerpts-energy-secretary-ernest-moniz-s-remarks-national-energy-technology-laboratory Excerpts of Energy Secretary Ernest Moniz’s Remarks at National Energy Technology Laboratory in Morgantown], [[United States Department of Energy]], 29 July 2013.</ref>}}
Then-US Energy Secretary [[Steven Chu]] and researchers for the US [[National Renewable Energy Laboratory]] have noted that greater electrical generation by non-[[Dispatchable generation|dispatchable]] renewables, such as wind and solar, will also increase the need for flexible natural gas-powered generators, to supply electricity during those times when solar and wind power are unavailable.<ref>April Lee and others, [http://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy13osti/56324.pdf Opportunities for synergy between natural gas and renewable energy], National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Dec. 2012.</ref><ref>John Funk, [http://www.cleveland.com/business/index.ssf/2012/01/doe_boss_says_shale_gas_could.html DOE boss says shale gas could benefit wind and solar], Cleveland Plain Dealer, 18 Jan. 2012.</ref> Gas-powered generators have the ability to ramp up and down quickly to meet changing loads.<ref>US EIA, [http://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.cfm?id=13191 Natural gas-fired combustion turbines are generally used to meet peak electricity load], 1 Oct. 2013.</ref>
In the US, many of the fossil fuel phase-out initiatives have taken place at the state or local levels.
[[File:California Electricity Sources 2010.png|thumb|left|California electricity generation by source, 2010 (data from US EIA)]] [[File:Maine Electricity Source.png|thumb|left|Sources of electricity generated in Maine. 2010 (US EIA)]] [[File:Texas Electricity Source.png|thumb|left|Sources of electricity generated in Texas, 2010 (US EIA)]] [[File:Washington state Electricity Source.png|thumb|left|Sources of electricity generation in Washington state, 2010 (US EIA)]]
==== California ==== [[California]]'s SB 1368 created the first governmental moratorium on new coal plants in the United States. The law was signed in September 2006 by [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Governor [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.energy.ca.gov/emission_standards/index.html |title=SB 1368 Emission Performance Standards |publisher=Energy.ca.gov |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref> took effect for investor-owned utilities in January 2007, and took effect for publicly owned utilities in August 2007. SB 1368 applied to long-term investments (five years or more) by California utilities, whether in-state or out-of-state. It set the standard for greenhouse gas emissions at 1,100 pounds of carbon dioxide per megawatt-hour, equal to the emissions of a combined-cycle natural gas plant. This standard created a de facto moratorium on new coal, since it could not be met without carbon capture and sequestration.<ref>[http://www.solutionsforglobalwarming.org/docs/SB1368_FS_FINAL.pdf "California Takes on Power Plant Emissions: SB 1368 Sets Groundbreaking Greenhouse Gas Performance Standard,"] [[Natural Resources Defense Council]] Fact Sheet, August 2007.</ref>
==== Maine ==== On April 15, 2008, [[Maine]] Governor [[John E. Baldacci]] signed LD 2126, "An Act To Minimize Carbon Dioxide Emissions from New Coal-Powered Industrial and Electrical Generating Facilities in the State." The law, which was sponsored by Rep. W. Bruce MacDonald (D-[[Boothbay, Maine|Boothbay]]), requires the Board of Environmental Protection to develop greenhouse gas emission standards for coal gasification facilities. It also puts a moratorium in place on building any new coal gasification facilities until the standards are developed.<ref>Rhonda Erskine, [http://www.wcsh6.com/news/article.aspx?storyid=84867 "Maine Governor Baldacci Signs Bill to Reduce Carbon Dioxide Emissions,"] [[WCSH]] [[WCSH6]].com, April 15, 2008</ref>
==== Oregon ==== In early March 2016, Oregon lawmakers approved a plan to stop paying for out-of-state coal plants by 2030 and require a 50 percent renewable energy standard by 2040.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/oregon-lawmakers-approve-far-reaching-climate-change-bill/ar-BBqiuvg?ocid=ansmsnnews11|title=Oregon lawmakers approve far-reaching climate change bill|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305215204/http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/oregon-lawmakers-approve-far-reaching-climate-change-bill/ar-BBqiuvg?ocid=ansmsnnews11|archivedate=5 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Environmental groups such as the [[American Wind Energy Association]] and leading Democrats praised the bill.
==== Texas ==== In 2006 a coalition of [[Texas]] groups organized a campaign in favor of a statewide moratorium on new coal-fired power plants. The campaign culminated in a "Stop the Coal Rush" mobilization, including rallying and lobbying, at the state capital in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] on February 11 and 12th, 2007.<ref>[http://texas.sierraclub.org/press/newsreleases/20070125.asp "Stop the Coal Rush" Rally & Lobby Day Set for February 11 & 12"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081030034206/http://texas.sierraclub.org/press/newsreleases/20070125.asp |date=30 October 2008 }}, [[Sierra Club]] Lone Star Chapter.</ref> Over 40 citizen groups supported the mobilization.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stopthecoalrush.com/participating-organizations/ |title=StopTheCoalRush - Hot Rush in Marketing |work=stopthecoalrush.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513110722/http://www.stopthecoalrush.com/participating-organizations/ |archivedate=13 May 2008 |df=dmy }}]</ref>
In January, 2007, A resolution calling for a 180-day moratorium on new pulverized coal plants was filed in the Texas Legislature by State Rep. [[Charles "Doc" Anderson]] (R-Waco) as House Concurrent Resolution 43.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legis.state.tx.us/tlodocs/80R/billtext/pdf/HC00043I.pdf|title=Text of HCR 43|publisher=}}</ref> The resolution was left pending in committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legis.state.tx.us/BillLookup/History.aspx?LegSess=80R&Bill=HCR43|title=Texas Legislature Online - 80(R) History for HCR 43|work=state.tx.us}}</ref> On December 4, 2007, Rep. Anderson announced his support for two proposed [[integrated gasification combined cycle]] (IGCC) coal plants proposed by [[Luminant]] (formerly TXU).<ref>[http://www.docandersonfortexas.com/news.htm Rep. Anderson press release] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828213707/http://www.docandersonfortexas.com/news.htm |date=28 August 2008 }}, December 4, 2007.</ref>
==== Washington state ==== [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] has followed the same approach as California, prohibiting coal plants whose emissions would exceed those of natural gas plants. Substitute Senate Bill 6001 (SSB 6001), signed on May 3, 2007, by Governor [[Christine Gregoire]], enacted the standard.<ref name="whitmanpioneer.com">Christina Russell, [http://whitmanpioneer.com/outdoors/2007/11/15/wallula-coal-plant-proposal-controversial-among-students-faculty/ "Wallula Coal Plant Proposal Controversial Among Students, Faculty,"] [[Whitman College]] Pioneer, 11/15/07</ref> As a result of SSB 6001, the [https://web.archive.org/web/20090716184525/http://www.energy-northwest.com/generation/igcc/index.php Pacific Mountain Energy Center] in Kalama was rejected by the state. However, a new plant proposal, the [http://www.wallulaenergy.com/ Wallula Energy Resource Center], shows the limits of the "natural gas equivalency" approach as a means of prohibiting new coal plants. The proposed plant would meet the standard set by SSB 6001 by capturing and sequestering a portion (65 percent, according to a plant spokesman) of its carbon.<ref name="whitmanpioneer.com"/>

=== Japan === Japan, the world's third-largest economy, made a major move to use more fossil fuels in 2012, when the nation shut down nuclear reactors following the Fukishima accident. Nuclear, which had supplied 30 percent of Japanese electricity from 1987 to 2011, supplied only 2 percent in 2012 (hydropower supplied 8 percent). Nuclear electricity was replaced with electricity from petroleum, coal, and liquified natural gas. As a result, electricity generation from fossil fuels rose to 90 percent in 2012.<ref>[https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=10391 "Japan’s fossil-fueled generation remains high because of continuing nuclear plant outages"], US Energy Information Administration, 15 March 2013.</ref>
In January 2017, the Japanese government announced plans to build 45 new coal-fired power plants in the next ten years, largely to replace expensive electricity from petroleum power plants.<ref>Babs McHugh, [http://www.platts.com/latest-news/coal/sydney/japan-plans-to-build-45-new-coal-power-plants-27762428 "Japan plans to build 45 coal power plants in next decade,"] Platts, 3 Feb. 2017.</ref>

=== Opinion polls ===
==== Opinion research ==== In October 2007, [http://www.civilsocietyinstitute.org/ Civil Society Institute] released the results of a poll of 1,003 US citizens conducted by Opinion Research Corporation.
The authors of the poll reported: "75 percent of Americans—including 65 percent of Republicans, 83 percent of Democrats and 76 percent of Independents—would 'support a five-year moratorium on new coal-fired power plants in the United States if there was stepped-up investment in clean, safe renewable energy—such as wind and solar—and improved home energy-efficiency standards.' Women (80 percent) were more likely than men (70 percent) to support this idea. Support also was higher among college graduates (78 percent) than among those who did not graduate from high school (68 percent)."<ref>Opinion Research Corporation, [http://www.cleanenergyaction.net/101807_CLEAN_survey_report.pdf A Post Fossil-Fuel America] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201122738/http://www.cleanenergyaction.net/101807_CLEAN_survey_report.pdf |date=1 December 2008 }}, Executive Summary, National Opinion Survey Produced for Citizens Lead for Energy Action Now (CLEAN), A Project of the Civil Society Institute, 18 October 2007</ref>
The exact question posed by the survey was as follows: "More than half of power plant-generated electricity comes from coal. Experts say that power plants are responsible for about 40 percent of U.S. carbon dioxide pollution linked to global warming. There are plans to build more than 150 new coal-fired power plants over the next several years. Would you support a five-year moratorium on new coal-fired power plants in the United States if there was stepped-up investment in clean, safe and renewable energy—such as wind and solar—and improved home energy-efficiency standards? Would you say definitely yes, probably yes, probably no, definitely no, or don't know."
The results were as follows:<ref>Opinion Research Corporation, [http://www.cleanenergyaction.net/101807_CLEAN_survey_report.pdf A Post Fossil-Fuel America] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201122738/http://www.cleanenergyaction.net/101807_CLEAN_survey_report.pdf |date=1 December 2008 }}, National Opinion Survey Produced for Citizens Lead for Energy Action Now (CLEAN), A Project of the Civil Society Institute, page 18, October 18, 2007</ref>
* 30% "definitely yes" * 45% "probably yes" * 13% "probably no" * 8% "definitely no" * 4% "don't know"
==== Gallup ==== In 2013, the Gallup organization determined that 41% of Americans wanted less emphasis placed on coal energy, versus 31% who wanted more. Large majorities wanted more emphasis placed on solar (76%), wind (71%), and natural gas (65%).<ref>Gallup, [http://www.gallup.com/poll/161519/americans-emphasis-solar-wind-natural-gas.aspx Americans want more emphasis on solar, wind, natural gas], 27 Mar. 2013.</ref>
==== ABC News/Washington Post ==== A 2009 ABC/Washington Post poll found 52% of Americans favored more coal mining (33% strongly favored), while 45% opposed (27% strongly opposed). The most support was for wind and solar, which were favored by 91% (79% strongly favored).<ref>ABC News/Washington Post, [http://abcnews.go.com/images/PollingUnit/1093a4Energy.pdf Energy policy has initial support], 28 August 2009.</ref>

The organization sees natural gas as a way to quickly replace coal, and that natural gas in time will be replaced by renewable energy.<ref>EDF, [http://www.edf.org/climate/why-natural-gas-important Why natural gas is important], accessed 4 Oct. 2013.</ref> The policy has been criticized by some environmentalists.<ref>Larry Bernstein, [https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-05-22/national/39441658_1_oil-companies-energy-companies-kennedy-jr Environmental Defense Fund scolded by other green organizations on ‘fracking’] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109052409/http://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-05-22/national/39441658_1_oil-companies-energy-companies-kennedy-jr |date=9 November 2013 }}, Washington Post, 22 May 2013.</ref> EDF counsel and blogger Mark Brownstein answered:
{{quote|Demand for natural gas is not going away, and neither is hydraulic fracturing. We must be clear-eyed about this, and fight to protect public health and the environment from unacceptable impacts. We must also work hard to put policies in place that ensure that natural gas serves as an enabler of renewable power generation, not an impediment to it. We fear that those who oppose all natural gas production everywhere are, in effect, making it harder for the U.S. economy to wean itself from dirty coal.|Mark Brownstein, EDF council<ref>Mark Brownstein, [http://blogs.edf.org/energyexchange/2012/09/10/why-edf-is-working-on-natural-gas/ Why EDF is working on natural gas], 10 Sept. 2012</ref>}}
